definition:
Let $R$ be a ring. A left ideal $I$ of $R$ is said to be *modular* if
there is an $e\in R$ such that $re-r\in I$ for all $r\in R$. In other
words, $e$ acts as a right identity element modulo $I$:
$$re\equiv r\pmod I.$$ A right modular ideal is defined similarly, with
$e$ be a left identity modulo $I$.

**Remark**. If an ideal $I$ is modular both as a left ideal as well as a
right ideal in $R$, then $R/I$ is a unital ring. Furthermore, every
(left, right, two-sided) ideal in a unital ring is modular, implying
that the notion of modular ideals is only interesting in rings without
$1$.
